ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic accounting skills: how to fill out and allocate different events in a company's history in the journal and transfer it to t accounts, cash flow statements, balance sheets, and the income statement. We also learned the direct and indirect method of accounting.

This class was a great overview of the fundamentals of  accounting , how financial valuation occurs, and the procedures used to create an accounting journal, t-accounts and financial statements. Professor Antle does a wonderful job building accounting knowledge throughout the semester.
Basic accounting skills. You will be able to answer interview questions on financial statements after this class.
Nitty-gritty accounting, with t-accounts and journal entries and balancing everything. Fun!
I learned accounting. Balance sheet, income statement, cash flow statements. I'm pretty comfortable with all of these.
This class actually teaches you accounting.

I learned how to preform valuations, the mechanics of accounting, how balance sheets, income statements, and cash flow statements work (and how to put them together). Also learned how to look at a company's 10k, interpret it, and formulate some of the aforementioned financial statements.
I learned the basics of accounting - valuation, how to make accounting entries using journals and T-accounts, prepare balance sheets, income statements, and cash flow statements.
Loved this course. Definitely the most practical econ class I've had at Yale. Feel like I can understand business talk much better now.
Great practical class with skills that you'll need for life.
Reading the financial statements, recognizing, posting and constructing financial statements from economic transactions. Basically a crash course on being an accountant

I greatly improved my accounting skills through this course. I now have a strong foundation of accounting knowledge that will be very useful in any summer internship in finance and/or related business fields. Though we didn't learn a lot of material, the fact that we spent so long reviewing and practicing the same concepts means that I won't forget them any time soon. You'll also come out of this course with a bunch of super useful spreadsheets.
I learned a plethoria of skills to analyze financial statements and correct errors in them.
knowledge of income statements, balance sheets, and cash flow statements.

Learnt about the process of making balance sheets, income statements, direct and indirect cash flow statements. Learnt about the connections between these, and how to work backwards from a financial statement (10-K) to figure out some transactions.
Basics of accounting
Comprehensive overview of accounting concepts.
I learned how to analyze a company's financial statements to identify account trends and best practices, as well as the relevant terminology.

We learned a lot about how to account for the time value of money, and how to derive meaning from the balance sheet, cash flow statement and income statement. We also learned how to create journal entries and these three statements from descriptions of company transactions.

Im an environmental studies major, and I learned the basics of the three financial statement, which is incredibly useful for going i to any field: the balance sheet, the income state statement, and the cash-flow sheets.
I learned basic accounting skills
You learn the basic intro skill needed for basic accountant work. As well as a working knowledge of interpreting cases of financial statements
The basics of accounting and finance. Valuation, debits and credits, fianancial statements.

Learned the basics of the three financial statements and how they all fit together. Awesome real-world skills and important topics covered in class. How to create financial statements and work quickly in Excel.

I feel that this course allowed me to really master the three principal statements in accounting (Balance Sheet, Income Statement, and Cash Flow Statement), and equipped me with a ton of useful knowledge concerning the present value of future cash flows, accounting for marketable securities, accounts receivable, and depreciation, and reading the financial statements of real-world companies.
Basics of financial statements

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: For an intro accounting course, the class was actually pretty difficult. Its probably not helpful since I can't exactly describe what it was, but I found the professor's method of teaching difficult to understand and it was very difficult to learn the concepts in class. I spent a lot of time outside of class trying to learn the material on my own (the book was much more helpful) through online sources and I spent a lot of time with other students working on the second problem set together. The second problem set took a significant amount of time to complete.

The course requires that students spend a lot of time practicing outside of class and correcting their assignments to ensure that they are correctly learning the material. While I think this is a good way to gain understanding of the material, I think the class would have been helped in understanding the material a little better if the Professor dedicated one day of class to going through an problem from beginning to end. The video that was produced in the middle of the semester was so helpful because it slowly went  through each step. There were a few steps that I had been over looking that-had I had the video or class review earlier, I wouldn't have overlooked them.
Rick did a great job of explaining the material.

Strength:  Professor Antle provided us with a super-advanced and very helpful version of an excel worksheet we could use on our assignments that I will be sure to pull out if I ever have to do accounting again.  He was flexible with homework and provided us with every opportunity to do our best work and produce the best results we could!

It's unfortunate that it meets on 8:45 at the SOM MW. If timing were any better, I'm sure class engagement would drastically improve, as the lectures are fine and Prof. Antle is engaging with his stories and passion.

It's pretty solid. You can't get worse than a B+ so that's a great way of making this somewhat pre-professional class be less intimidating. Lectures were somewhat hit or miss, but toward the end it got really interesting.

The lectures are rather dry and the assignments are due before they are introduced in class. They can be redone on later dates, but it makes it difficult for the first time around when it's all new material. The skills this course gives are so practical, though, that makes it worthwhile.

The existence of this class is a great strength - I am so happy Yale offers a class that teaches students a practical skill set that will be useful for whatever they do after graduation. I think Yale students have a hunger for more of these types of classes. Professor Antle is a FANTASTIC teacher - he makes this class accessible to anyone (no matter math or econ background) and is very accommodating/understanding of different students' learning needs. He cares a lot about this class and does his utmost to help students learn the material - even making custom videos for viewing online. I especially appreciate his willingness to help me access an individual QR tutor through the CTL, which made all the difference for me this semester. Also THANK GOODNESS for the option to have no in-class exams! 

In terms of weaknesses, it was often hard for me to complete the homework because, in some cases, I really had no idea where to start. If there were more videos online to go along with these problems, to walk a student through doing the problem, I think that would be really helpful.

Fantastic course for accounting. It was very well organized and the professor was great, extremely approachable, and had the sole goal of making sure everything we did and learned was for a purpose. Deadlines were very flexible. No weaknesses I can think of
The lectures were super engaging but sometimes got off track.

The strengths of this course are the online teaching material that Professor Antle presents to accompany his teaching. The major weakness is that it's taught so early at the School of Management. This is only compounded by the fact that Professor Antle is not the most engaging lecturer and accounting isn't the most engaging subject.
Very well taught. Material was interesting and useful.
It's a very well designed course for its purposes.
Great instructor and curriculum
The strengths of this course were the experience of the professors, and willingness to help by the TAs. The weaknesses of this course was how early the class met in the mornings.

I thought the course was taught in a way that allowed beginners to get up to speed with everyone who had had some experience with accounting before. The first few weeks we focused on time value of money which could probably have been condensed into fewer classes. I liked the way the class was graded, based on completion and effort.
I think the class was very well run. More videos would be very helpful to be able to able to work through things on our own time. Also a video of the final.

The course is very tailored to helping a liberal arts student learn practical accounting skills. The weakness is that there wasn't strong feedback from TAs with the grading which made it difficult to ensure that the material was being learned correctly.
Great course, however, I wish there were a midterm or some other graded activity earlier in the course so that the final grade was not completely dependent on the final exam.

The strengths of this course are its daily online problems, which helped to keep me on top of the material, its problem sets/exams, which were fair and never too burdensome, and its professor, who is very sensitive to the needs of his students.  The only weakness of the course is that it spends too little time covering the difficult topics presented in the last few weeks (accounting for accounts receivable, accounting for marketable securities, etc.).

Strengths: professor teaches well and covers nuances, goal of the class is very learning oriented which is nice

Weaknesses: holy shit please don't make this a 8:45AM at SOM again, this really gets in the way of people enjoying this class. this class would be VASTLY improved and ratings would increase by not changing anything and moving it to a noon or afternoon time slot

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student since it's the only accounting course offered at Yale. That being said, be prepared to spend a lot of time outside of class reading the book as well as other online material and videos to make sure you understand the material. Accounting itself is straightforward, but for some reason it never clicked in class.
Yes, this course is a great way to understand the fundamentals of accounting. This is useful information for anyone who is considering any business profession.
I developed a basic understanding of accounting. Would recommend to every undergrad student.

Yes, it's a must-take class if you are looking into a finance career. I am pretty shocked by how many Yalies going into their IB or finance internships without solid accounting skills. Don't be one of them.

I learned the fundamentals of accounting. Specifically how to get in balance on excel.  Professor Antle provided us with a super-advanced and very helpful version of an excel worksheet we could use on our assignments that I will be sure to pull out if I ever have to do accounting again.
Essential for anyone going into finance. Otherwise, if you can stomach 8:45 at the SOM, go ahead!

Yes, if you're a future finance bro(/bra) or entrepreneur, you should know accounting basics. Since you literally cannot do worse than a B+ if you submit everything, it's quite a low risk, high reward class. (I've been told by a friend in the class that) You can full grades on the regular "quizzes," which are online and open-book, even with partial and very incorrect completion. 

Professor Antle is so knowledgeable about the area, and he works you through the process quite thoughtfully. By the end, I was able to go between the balance sheet, income statement, and statements of cash flows easily. 

Best of all, I successfully petitioned this class to count for Econ major credit. That, combined with the minimum grade of B+, lends it to be a particularly great class.

Yes, if you at all interested in things related to accounting--financial statements, valuation, time basis of accounting--then take it. It's one of the few courses that gave really practical skills, as opposed to majority being theoretical work. Keep in mind it does require you keep up the material (which can be difficult to do).

If you're going to take an accounting class, THIS is the one to take. Professor Antle is awesome. He really cares about the learning of all his students and is quite accommodating. He makes the early class time well worth it. As a non-business/math/econ person, I found this class accessible and valuable. It feels good to learn a hard skill that will be useful for whatever you do after Yale. There are no in-class exams (unless you take the option in-class final to get above a B+) - just 2 psets, daily homework, and a take-home final. The way the grading is set up, it's a good option for Cr/D/F if you're averse to getting below an A. I'd highly recommend it to anyone - you will learn the basics of accounting!
Absolutely, Rick was the bomb. Literally the worst grade you can get is a B+ which is huge. Well taught and I feel like I gained a lot.
Yes I would- accounting basics are helpful for all to know.

The course starts off with some basic Math and quickly accelerates to the small details of the GAAP- Generally Accepted Accounting Principle towards the end. I think being able to read financial statements is a good skill to have, though the course seems to have a much stronger focus on constructing the financial statement. For a majority of the students, this is a little overkilling unless you want to start a career of an accountant or auditor.

Don't kid yourself, you will NOT wake up at 8:30am to go to an accounting class at the School of Management 2 times a week. You'll go strong for the first month, realize that you can succeed in class by just reading the posted lecture slides, and then stop going completely. But Professor Antle realizes this and structures the course around it! If you put in even a quarter of the effort of a regular Yale class, you'll do incredibly well in this class. The problem is that it's just sooooo hard to get yourself to put effort into this class because everything except the optional in-class final is graded for completion. If you do all the assignments and don't do the in-class final, you'll get a B+. If you do the in-class final, you can get higher than a B+. This is how easy the class is. There is no reason to not take it.
Yes. The Professor is amazing. Extremely knowledgeable, interesting, and responds quickly to emails.
this class met at 8:45am in a SOM classroom. Would not recommend
Yes. Professor Rick is great, and material is useful.
It's a great course to take to learn the basics of accounting.
Yes, if youre interested in accounting
Yes, if you want to gain deep understanding of accounting. No, if you dont plan on ever going into finance.

If you're interested in learning basic concepts in accounting, in preparation for an internship or for your own personal reasons, the class is right for you. Otherwise, stick to more theoretical and less applied classes.

I took this class credit/D and COMPLETELY recommend. Its a great way to get an intro to the basics of finance, which can serve you in any field  myself being an EVST major. Just make the effort to show up to class, so yourself that favor.
If interested in accounting, I would recommend this course to these students. The course makes it really easy to learn the material, especially if not an economics major.
Yes its a good intro accounting course
Yes, important concepts covered whether or not you are planning on working in a financial related field.

Yes!  It is critical if you want to run a business someday, go into finance, become an accountant, or even practice law.  I felt like I had absolutely mastered the fundamentals of accounting by the end of the course.
Practical course that's well taught by a professor who cares. Difficulty is only average (especially if you're a STEM person).
Great intro to the basic financial statements if you can get yourself to consistently go to an 8:45AM class at SOM. If you can, would recommend
